item.title: Christie add a quote by Tom Stoppard
item.description: "Pirates could happen to anyone." -- Tom Stoppard

item.title: Christie add a quote by Balzac
item.description: "I am not deep, but I am very wide." -- Balzac

item.title: Christie add a quote by Gary Snyder
item.description: "As a poet I hold the most archaic values on earth . . . the fertility of the soil, the magic of animals, the power-vision in solitude, the terrifying initiation and rebirth, the love and ecstasy of the dance, the common work of the tribe. I try to hold both history and the wilderness in mind, that my poems may approach the true measure of things and stand against the unbalance and ignorance of our times." -- Gary Snyder

item.title: Christie add a quote by Thornton Wilder
item.description: "Once you have swung a pickax that will reveal the curve of a street four thousand years covered over which was once an active, much-traveled highway, you are never quite the same again." -- Thornton Wilder

item.title: Christie add a quote by August Wilson
item.description: "Confront the dark parts of yourself, and work to banish them with illumination and forgiveness. Your willingness to wrestle with your demons will cause your angels to sing." -- August Wilson

item.title: Christie add a quote by Wendell Berry
item.description: "Better than any argument is to rise at dawn and pick dew-wet red berries in a cup." -- Wendell Berry

item.title: Christie add a quote by John Cheever
item.description: "Weeding the peony hedge I hear the windfalls in the orchard; hear them strike the ground, hear them strike against branches as they fall to the ground. The immemorial smell of apples, old as the sea. Mary makes jelly. Up from the kitchen, up the stairs and into all the rooms comes the smell of apples." -- John Cheever

item.title: Christie add a quote by William Saroyan
item.description: "The role of art is to make a world which can be inhabited." -- William Saroyan

item.title: Christie add a quote by Pierre Bonnard
item.description: "Speaking, when you have something to say, is like looking. But who looks? If people could see properly, and see whole, they would all be painters. And it's because people have no idea how to look that they hardly ever understand." -- Pierre Bonnard

item.title: Christie add a quote by Tom Stoppard
item.description: "We cross our bridges when we come to them and burn them behind us, with nothing to show for our progress except a memory of the smell of smoke, and a presumption that once our eyes watered." -- Tom Stoppard

item.title: Christie add a quote by Rainer Maria Rilke
item.description: "Across the moment, aeons speak with aeons. More than we experienced has gone by." -- Rainer Maria Rilke

item.title: Christie add a quote by Mary McCarthy
item.description: "You can date the evolving life of a mind, like the age of a tree, by the rings of friendship formed by the expanding central trunk." -- Mary McCarthy

item.title: Christie add a quote by G. K. Chesterton
item.description: "You say grace before meals. All right. But I say grace before the concert and the opera, and grace before the play and pantomime, and grace before I open a book, and grace before sketching, painting, swimming, fencing, boxing, walking, playing, dancing and grace before I dip the pen in the ink." -- G. K. Chesterton

item.title: Christie add a quote by e.e. cummings
item.description: "To be nobody but yourself in a world which is doing its best day and night to make you like everybody else means to fight the hardest battle which any human being can fight and never stop fighting." -- e.e. cummings

item.title: Christie add a quote by Rumi
item.description: "Who could be so lucky? Who comes to a lake for water and sees the reflection of moon." -- Rumi

item.title: Christie add a quote by Padma Hejmadi
item.description: "It is, after all, that old process which Katherine Mansfield once described as â€˜going out and looking at a tree and coming back plus the tree." -- Padma Hejmadi

item.title: Christie add a quote by A.A. Milne
item.description: "When stuck in the river, it is best to dive and swim to the bank yourself before someone drops a large stone on your chest in an attempt to hoosh you there." -- A.A. Milne

item.title: Christie add a quote by George Bernard Shaw
item.description: "After all, the wrong road always leads somewhere." -- George Bernard Shaw
